Lowering human greenhouse gas emissions is a major goal of efforts against climate change, as emphasized by the Paris Agreement (2015). Many indicators of human development, such as population, Gross Domestic Product (GDP), and environmental footprint, have followed exponential curves over the past decades (Steffen et al., 2015). To switch from increasing to decreasing emissions, drastic measures are needed, as stated in global organizations' goals (IPCC Fifth Assessment Report, 2014). Understanding and forecasting the evolution of various indicators related to carbon emissions on a country scale can help assess progress towards lower emissions.

We chose to study the variables appearing in the Kaya identity (Kaya & Yokoburi, 1997) on a country level: population, national GDP, energy supply, and CO2 emissions. Our main objective is to develop a model that uses this data to make accurate forecasts on a medium- to long-term horizon. Machine-learning models offer advantages over traditional methods, such as statistical models (Cerqueira et al., 2019). The recent development of Neural Ordinary Differential Equations (Chen et al., 2019) offers a promising perspective in this case.

We adapted Neural ODEs for this problem and compared their performance with a baseline statistical model. 

The Kaya identity expresses a simple relation between carbon emissions, energy supply, GDP, and population: F = P * G * P * E * G * F / E. The GDP per capita (G) represents our average life standard, which we generally want to increase. The energy intensity of the GDP (E) quantifies the efficiency of energy usage in our activities. The carbon intensity of energy (E) indicates how reliant on carbon emissions our electricity production is.

Forecasting human development and carbon emissions is possible with both the set of raw variables (P, G, E, F) and the set of indicators appearing in the Kaya identity (P, G, G, E, F). However, the latter gives a clearer analysis from a macroscopic point of view (Ritchie & Roser, b). Using these four indicators seems to be a good choice to assess efforts made by a country or region concerning carbon emissions (Streimikien ˇe & Balezentis, 2016).

We used four datasets for this study: population and GDP from the World Bank Open Data platform, and total energy supply and CO2 emissions from the International Energy Agency. Each variable is available yearly, from 1971 to 2019, for at least 54 countries.

In the domain of energy and emissions, forecasts often rely on expert knowledge and statistical models (York et al., 2003; Auffhammer & Steinhauser, 2008). An extensive set of Integrated Assessment Models are used to explore how the Earth system evolves during the next decades, following specific scenarios (IPCC Fifth Assessment Report, 2014).
